page.title: 11LANGUAGE IN CRUWYS MORCHARD
page.content: Many accents are heard, brought by incomers, but the characteristic burr, the rolling of the 'r' of the native Devonian, remains undiluted. Dialect is fast disappearing, only a few words and phrases persist, such as to 'terrify' meaning to tease. Accent is difficult to convey but try these: maezed=stupid apse=fasten scummer=fuss dimpsey=twilight wopsie=wasp yaw=ewe proper=fine get-paust=gate-post marl-scrarl=caterpillar dashel=thistle sot=set suant=smooth wisht=pale-faced quatt=flat yer=ear,hear,here ayed=head maed=small girl maeden=older girl bied=stay gurt=large vore=fore,main tawd=toad,naughty child gaek=stare falled abroad=become stout dayed=dead 'To' is frequently added to a phrase and'we' replaced by 'us'. 'Us'll bide yer where we'm to, sot down in middle o' Dem.'
